THE HOMEWOOD COMMITTEE

Five Hopkins Men Are Entitled to Places
on All-Star Aggregation—Western Maryland Has Three.

Games in Basket-Ball League Are Hard
Fought—Freshmen to Contest
for Medals and Banner.

Noted Philadelphia Neurologist to be the
Commemoration Orator—Subject,
"George Washington."

Will Have Charge of Building Operations
at Homewood—Mr. Bouton
to Assist in Work.

Tiin NEws-LETTER publishes below its selections for an all-Maryland football eleven:

The gymnasium saw some pretty
basket-ball games on Tuesday, December 5. No. I team, consisting
of Dickey, Todes, Brown, White,
and Kuehn, defeated No. 4, consisting of Cooke, Schmeisser, Elliott,
Goldman, and Sousley, by the score
of 18 to 6. No. 3 defeated No. 2
by 18 to 5. No. 3 contains Uhler,
Tull, Huck, Breuninger, Jacobs and
Myer; No. 2 contains Supplee,
Price, Wharton, Weems, and Belt.
On Thursday, the gymnasium, because of the fact that the Glee Club
was rehearsing for the Rockville
entertainment was not so well attended. No. i team played its rival,
No. 3, and won, 14 to 4. No. 2
and No. 4 engaged in a scrappy
game, ending with a victory for No.
2. The score was 13 to 5. The
standing of the teams are as follows:

The freshman class is soon to be
divided into two parts, the Green
and the White. Captains have already been elected to get an idea
of the abilities of each man, so as
to be able to choose sides later. The
captains are Thompson and Voshell.
Each will choose as assistant captains two men from Hutzler, Biser,
Troxell, and Prinz. These six men
were elected by the gymnasium
class.
In order to secure medals and
trophies for the winners in the
basket-ball leagues and for the winners in the competition among the
freshmen, Mr. Kistler will try to
get help from the Athletic Association.

Announcement was made by
President Remsen last week that
Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell of Philadelphia would be the main speaker
at the Commemoration Exercises
on February 22, 1911.
Dr. Mitchell is one of the most
prominent of American scholars,
being famous both as a doctor of
medicine and an author. His main
field of work is in medicine, and
he is a fellow of several foreign
medical associations and a member
of the National Academy, U. S. A.
He is an eminent neurologist and
physiologist. He claims that writing is his avocation, and that when
he is tired of laboring in the clinical
fields he finds great rest and relaxation in writing novels. Besides
having written almost a hundred
famous pamphlets on medical topics, he has written a score of
widely-read novels. His "Hugh
Wynne, Free Quaker ;" "Constance
Trescott," and "The Red City"
have all been best sellers. Another, of his. hobbies _,.is_writing
poetry. "The Mother," and "The
Cup of Youth," are considered his
best works in this department. His
vacation time is almost always spent
in salmon fishing in the wild northwestern river-beds.
It will be remembered that Dr.
Mitchell spoke here last year under
the auspices of the Historical Association of the Medical School,.
He spoke on the life and works of
Dr. William Harvey, the discoverer
of blood circulation.
Dr. Mitchell is 82 year old, and
is called by his friends the "grand
old man of Philadelphia." His
topic at the Commemoration Exercises will be "George Washington."

The choice was made, with the
exception of the two men from
Washington College, on the basis
of the showing in the games at
Homewood, for the best football
of the season in Maryland was
Played by the Hopkins 'Varsity and
its opponents.
No one will dispute the right of
l'\vigg and Sprague of Western
Maryland to hold their positions.
Both are good on the offensive and
in close football, while in forward
Passes they haven't any equal in
the East. The right of Morton to
hold down the other end, and the
.claim of Bridgman to be one of the
half backs, are also undisputed.
Shipley of Maryland Agricultural
College is made quarter back because
he is a good field general, a reliable drop-kicker, and excellent on
end runs. Gillet is given the other
back position, because he is one of
the best punters in the State, and
because on the offensive, especially
in the St. John's, and Western
-\ I aryland games, he did wonderful
Work.
The other positions are given to
the men who showed up best in
the games in the intercollegiate
series. There was no spectacular
Work, but Graefe, of Western
Maryland; Wilkinson, of Washington College, and Liebensperger, of
Hopkins, played consistently. In
the Hopkins-Western Maryland
contest, it was really the winner's
tackles who decided the result, as
they broke through often and their
worl on the defensive stopped the
'Varsity's gains time and time
again.
It will be gratifying to Hopkins
supporters to know that so many
men who wore Black and Blue
colors during the past season
deserve places on the all-Maryland

Forty New Matriculates.

Last Thursday, at five o'clock,
President Remsen and Dean Griffin
met all students who have fully
matriculated. Dr. Remsen welcomed all and spoke briefly about
customs that are found only in
Hopkins. He was followed by Dr.
Bliss, who emphasized that the college student of today should keep
in touch with affairs not only near
him, but also with important happenings abroad, and that he should
choose a profession in which he
thinks he can excel. Then Dr.
'Warden related an interesting experience that befell him while in
Spain. He was followed by Dean
Griffin, who spoke briefly. This
year 40 students have fully matriculated, 22 of whom are freshmen,

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be endorsed with the name of the writer,
which, upon request, will be withheld.)

December 6, 1911.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

mals and moral men. All over the
country Y. M. C. A.'s and Y. W.
C. A.'s have been organized to interest men and women in something higher than the dance halls.
Everywhere charity organizations
are trying to prevent poverty and
vice. Churches have begun to do
institutional work. Crime is being
studied, so that it can be stopped.
But most important of all, colleges
all over the land are offering courses
in sociology. Thus the leaders of
tomorrow are being taught how the
other half lives; so that tomorrow,
directly or indirectly, they can help
to make this world a better place
to live in.
As yet the Johns Hopkins University has not offered a course in
sociology. Will not the University
authorities consider seriously the
advisability of introducing such a
course? If we can judge from the
immediate success such courses
have achieved in other universities,
if we can judge from the number of
men who are taking Political Economy I, if we can judge from the
number of men who have expressed
a desire to take such a course, if
we can judge from the number of
men at Hopkins who are preparing for the ministry, such a course
would be highly successful. The
world needs the intelligent interest
and support of every college man
in this battle to uplift our less fortunate brothers. In order that we
may give the support she asks, we
must be instructed in the elements
of sociology. A member of this
University said to me that although
he knew there was a great deal of
evil going on in our city, he did not
know how to help stop it. He asked
me what he should do when he became a man. Many of us are asking similar questions. We should
like very much to be answered.

The writer is a freshman at Hopkins, and begs for enough space
to complain of the absence of wastepaper baskets in those parts of the
University which he frequents. He
has seen only two of these necessities in McCoy Hall-one in the
office of the registrar and one in
the basement, near the postoffice.
In all of the classrooms he visits
in this building there are no receptacles for waste paper. Is he,
when he has paper to throw away,
to be compelled to walk to the registrar's office or the basement? In
the physics laboratory, where the
writer attends his mathematics
class, he has 'yet to have the pleasure of seeing a proper place to
throw waste paper and old test
papers.
It appears that I am not the
only student needing this commodity. Last week I saw a sophomore,
"bold and cruel," walk hurriedly
out of a classroom on the second
floor of McCoy Hall and go half
way down the stairs to the landing
to place a handful of finely torn-up
paper in the large green tub in
which a rubber plant grows. Then
he went back up stairs. I also
noticed a student in the physics
laboratory raise a window in that
building and throw out in the street

justices. There is only one man
in every 750, reaching 21 years,
who has been a college graduate.
A college education, therefore, increases its possessor's opportunities
of reaching political eminence in
the United States from 240 fold,
in the case of congressmen, to
620 fold in the case of chief justices of the Supreme Court. This
is a much larger ratio than is the
case with lower positions. But what
is the percentage of college men to
obtain such eminence? Please,somebody, figure it out, and then we will
know better what chance we have
of having our pictures in the paper,
and being investigated for something we did to get there.

THE NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 11, 191.1.
Outside Impressions.

Co-eds'Cozy Corner
December 7, 1911.
To the Editor of

THE NEWS-LETTER:

That was a clever and interesting
article on "Meeting the Co-eds
and Then —," in the last issue of
THE NEWS-LETTER, but the logic
was all wrong, and no self-respecting "co-ed" would ever permit herself to be "picked up" in this
fashion.
The male undergraduate is a
species which I never could understand. I recall a villainous one to
Whom I was once formally introduced. This was at the college I
attended before coming to Johns
Hopkins. I had maintained speaking relations with this young man
for two weeks and then we met at
a frat affair and somehow he
brought me home.
It was moonlight and it is said
that moonlight is responsible for
many crimes. That I do not know,
but I do know that after he had unlocked the door and was saying
good night," he kissed me. Think
of it! two weeks' acquaintance, and
a kiss—not a mere attempt.
An innocent girl like me! I
Shrank from him in horror, and I
• think that when that villain saw the
look of contempt and anger in my
eyes he was half sorry. I panted
With indignation. I strove to pull
myself together sufficiently to express the scorn which was surging
in my bosom. I thought of the
heating which he would get when
I told my father of the occurrence.
I thought of the subsequent publicity; the long, illustrated accounts
of this awful crime and the punishment which would appear in the
Papers when the correspondents got
Wind of the story.
Hat in hand, and head bowed
down, he turned to go. My blazing eyes and crimson cheeks told
!lim it was dangerous to remain
longer. I was in evening dress with
no hatpins; but hair pins are no
mean weapons in a pinch. He
seemed afraid to speak out and I
struggled to find words before he
left to express my contempt. I
determined to find words or die in
the attempt.
"When," I finally asked, in a low,
faltering voice, full of deep-seated
hatred, "are you coming again ?"
'rhe rest I leave to your imagination.
Co-education may be all right,
but I came to Johns Hopkins to
study and after that episode at
College, I lost two evenings
a week to this villainous young
man, and when we parted his heart
nearly broke.
No more undergraduates for me.
When I need diversion I go to the
moving pictures, and as for being
"Picked up," that would be the last
thing I'd ever consent to. I want
tO study, and my subjects will not
be men. There will be time enough
for that, for I am still young.
Please do not publish my name.
k

CO-ED.

One of the things that strikes a
person here at Hopkins is the really
double life that the students lead.
A student could be the most abandoned, rip-roaring sinner imaginable after class hours, and nobody
would be any the wiser. We gather
here for a few hours each day, see
each other and think we know each
other; do we? How many of us
know with whom any of the rest
of us eat, with whom they spend
their idle hours, or where their
favorite haunts are situated? A
man could eat all his meals at the
Goldfield Hotel, have "Al" Herford for his bosom friend, and spend
all his evenings at Westport, without his university "friends" thinking him anything but a very proper
fellow. Some conveniences in not
being out at Homewood yet, aren't
there?
A man who visits Levering Hall
will find all of the students there
doing one of two things: frantically
writing out exercises or stupidly
dozing. The same condition of affairs seems to exist in the library.
The reason isn't far to seek. By
the time a man has completed all
his class assignments and taken the
amount of physical exercise necesgary to keep him in health, he
doesn't feel fit for much of anything but sleep. No browsing
among the poets in these classic
halls! No time for Woodrow Wilson clubs or such things! We afford a noble example of concentration. Our aims are unified, our
reading is systematized, our otherwise wandering faculties are directed into the straight channel of science and health.
Has the difference between a
course in composition and a course
in Latin, or physics, or political
economy ever been pointed out? In
Latin, or political economy, or physics, a man who reads in a book long
and faithfully enough is bound to
do excellent work. He gets something out of the book and in recitation hands it back to the professor.
In a composition course the work is
purely original. The student finds
his material where Ile can. He must
select what he will use and what
he will reject. That which he
chooses to use he must classify, arrange, proportion and then express.
Some difference, isn't there?

Last Wednesday, Dr. Finney appeared before one of his classes
which had not seen him since he
refused the presidency of Princeton. As he came into the room
the students began clapping very
loudly. The action was evidently
quite unexpected by Dr. Pinney.
He turned red as a beet and after
remaining speechless for several
minutes, exclaimed: "Gentlemen,
you are not half as glad as I am."

THE NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 11, 1911.
COLUMBIA'S WAGE EARNERS
Earnings of Students in Various EmPloyments Last Year Were $75,700.
Employment Committee's Work.

Students at Columbia University
during the year ended May, 1911,
earned $75,700. This amount is below the student earnings of the preceding year, but according to the
report of the Employment Committee, recently issued from the University, there were more places filled
by the Committee than in any other
single year. Furthermore, the success of the men employed has given
the Committee a prestige that it has
never before enjoyed and opened up
employment which was closed to
university students.
An explanation of the striking decrease of the total earnings of the
students in the past academic year
as compared with the high-water
mark of the year before, when earnings were $166,778, is given in the
report. "This discrepancy of nearly
$100,000," the report says, "is exPlained by the fact that excepting
the records for the summer vacation of 1910, the Committee endeavored to obtain a report of the
earnings of only those students actuallY registered in the Committee's
list, whereas previously all the students in the University were requested to furnish a record of their
earnings. Instead of asking 4,000
students to report their earnings,
the Committee asked only 820, the
number applying for employment."
Since the first report of the Comniittee for the year 1898-1899 was
Published, the student earnings have
amounted to a total of $904,003.
With the Committee's aid, earnings were $296,445, and without the
Committee's aid, $607,558. The
ratio of earnings with and without
the Committee's aid apparently remains the same from year to year,
although it varies as to the number
of students, who look more to their
own efforts to obtain employment
rather than to those of the Committee to obtain employment for them.
An interesting point is brought
out in the report in regard to freshmen obtaining employment such as
will support them for the first year.
It is only the exceptional man that
can count on paying his way during
this initial year.
•
-About fifty students find employment as stenographers," says the report, "and students coming to the
University with a knowledge of stenography and typewriting will find
it particularly easy to get something
to do. Nearly every one who applied for typewriting work got at
least a small amount. No other class
of work includes more than 2 per
cent, of the number of positions
filled, among the other most popular
demands being camp and hotel
Work, and that in social settlements.
"Teaching paid graduate students
best, for they earned a total of $6,30 without and $3,609 with the

students come second, totaling $1,-

E. B. TAYLOR

Dr. L. L. Uhl, A. B., '89, before
his university course in the Johns
Hopkins University, opened a high
school in Guntur, British India, in
1873, working until it was ripe
for the establishment of a college,
in 1885. He is now principal of
this college.
Where, in 1873, there were not
800 students of all ages and sexes
in Guntur, there are now 3,940 pupils. The college and the General
Synod Lutheran Mission, with
which Dr. Uhl is connected, are
responsible for the majority of these
students and for the largest part of
the many educational changes;
2,179 of the whole number of pupils being in.the college and its high
school, the high school for girls,
and other mission schools, of which
there are, all told, twenty-four mission schools in the town. These
schools are under eight different
American men and women of the
mission.
Guntur is an interior town of
40,000 population and with good
business in argicultural productions.
Long-Distance Nerve.
The city editor of one of the
New York afternoon papers has a
wonderful nose for news, but is
lacking somewhat in a sense of
humor. Once he sent a new reporter up to Harlem to put certain
personal questions to a gentleman
ns ined Flannagan, whose wife had
eloped with a grocery clerk. An
hour passed and then the new reporter called up his city editor on
the telephone, and in a trembling,
shaken voice he said:
"Mr. Blank, I'm nearly killed. I
told Flannagan what you told me
to ask him, and he choked me and
struck me and kicked me all the
way down three flights of steps.
And he says that if I dare to come
back he will kill me."
"Look here," shouted the city
editor; "you go back and find that
man Flannagan and tell him he
can't intimidate me!"— Saturday
Evoling Post.

THE HOMEWOOD COMMITTEE

Five Hopkins Men Are Entitled to Places
on All-Star Aggregation—Western Maryland Has Three.

Games in Basket-Ball League Are Hard
Fought—Freshmen to Contest
for Medals and Banner.

Noted Philadelphia Neurologist to be the
Commemoration Orator—Subject,
"George Washington."

Will Have Charge of Building Operations
at Homewood—Mr. Bouton
to Assist in Work.

Tiin NEws-LETTER publishes below its selections for an all-Maryland football eleven:

The gymnasium saw some pretty
basket-ball games on Tuesday, December 5. No. I team, consisting
of Dickey, Todes, Brown, White,
and Kuehn, defeated No. 4, consisting of Cooke, Schmeisser, Elliott,
Goldman, and Sousley, by the score
of 18 to 6. No. 3 defeated No. 2
by 18 to 5. No. 3 contains Uhler,
Tull, Huck, Breuninger, Jacobs and
Myer; No. 2 contains Supplee,
Price, Wharton, Weems, and Belt.
On Thursday, the gymnasium, because of the fact that the Glee Club
was rehearsing for the Rockville
entertainment was not so well attended. No. i team played its rival,
No. 3, and won, 14 to 4. No. 2
and No. 4 engaged in a scrappy
game, ending with a victory for No.
2. The score was 13 to 5. The
standing of the teams are as follows:

The freshman class is soon to be
divided into two parts, the Green
and the White. Captains have already been elected to get an idea
of the abilities of each man, so as
to be able to choose sides later. The
captains are Thompson and Voshell.
Each will choose as assistant captains two men from Hutzler, Biser,
Troxell, and Prinz. These six men
were elected by the gymnasium
class.
In order to secure medals and
trophies for the winners in the
basket-ball leagues and for the winners in the competition among the
freshmen, Mr. Kistler will try to
get help from the Athletic Association.

Announcement was made by
President Remsen last week that
Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell of Philadelphia would be the main speaker
at the Commemoration Exercises
on February 22, 1911.
Dr. Mitchell is one of the most
prominent of American scholars,
being famous both as a doctor of
medicine and an author. His main
field of work is in medicine, and
he is a fellow of several foreign
medical associations and a member
of the National Academy, U. S. A.
He is an eminent neurologist and
physiologist. He claims that writing is his avocation, and that when
he is tired of laboring in the clinical
fields he finds great rest and relaxation in writing novels. Besides
having written almost a hundred
famous pamphlets on medical topics, he has written a score of
widely-read novels. His "Hugh
Wynne, Free Quaker ;" "Constance
Trescott," and "The Red City"
have all been best sellers. Another, of his. hobbies _,.is_writing
poetry. "The Mother," and "The
Cup of Youth," are considered his
best works in this department. His
vacation time is almost always spent
in salmon fishing in the wild northwestern river-beds.
It will be remembered that Dr.
Mitchell spoke here last year under
the auspices of the Historical Association of the Medical School,.
He spoke on the life and works of
Dr. William Harvey, the discoverer
of blood circulation.
Dr. Mitchell is 82 year old, and
is called by his friends the "grand
old man of Philadelphia." His
topic at the Commemoration Exercises will be "George Washington."

The choice was made, with the
exception of the two men from
Washington College, on the basis
of the showing in the games at
Homewood, for the best football
of the season in Maryland was
Played by the Hopkins 'Varsity and
its opponents.
No one will dispute the right of
l'\vigg and Sprague of Western
Maryland to hold their positions.
Both are good on the offensive and
in close football, while in forward
Passes they haven't any equal in
the East. The right of Morton to
hold down the other end, and the
.claim of Bridgman to be one of the
half backs, are also undisputed.
Shipley of Maryland Agricultural
College is made quarter back because
he is a good field general, a reliable drop-kicker, and excellent on
end runs. Gillet is given the other
back position, because he is one of
the best punters in the State, and
because on the offensive, especially
in the St. John's, and Western
-\ I aryland games, he did wonderful
Work.
The other positions are given to
the men who showed up best in
the games in the intercollegiate
series. There was no spectacular
Work, but Graefe, of Western
Maryland; Wilkinson, of Washington College, and Liebensperger, of
Hopkins, played consistently. In
the Hopkins-Western Maryland
contest, it was really the winner's
tackles who decided the result, as
they broke through often and their
worl on the defensive stopped the
'Varsity's gains time and time
again.

choose a profession in which he

Spain. He was followed by Dean
Griffin, who spoke briefly. This
year 40 students have fully matriculated, 22 of whom are freshmen,

December 6, 1911.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

mals and moral men. All over the
country Y. M. C. A.'s and Y. W.
C. A.'s have been organized to interest men and women in something higher than the dance halls.
Everywhere charity organizations
are trying to prevent poverty and
vice. Churches have begun to do
institutional work. Crime is being
studied, so that it can be stopped.
But most important of all, colleges
all over the land are offering courses
in sociology. Thus the leaders of
tomorrow are being taught how the
other half lives; so that tomorrow,
directly or indirectly, they can help
to make this world a better place
to live in.
As yet the Johns Hopkins University has not offered a course in
sociology. Will not the University
authorities consider seriously the
advisability of introducing such a
course? If we can judge from the
immediate success such courses
have achieved in other universities,
if we can judge from the number of
men who are taking Political Economy I, if we can judge from the
number of men who have expressed
a desire to take such a course, if
we can judge from the number of
men at Hopkins who are preparing for the ministry, such a course
would be highly successful. The
world needs the intelligent interest
and support of every college man
in this battle to uplift our less fortunate brothers. In order that we
may give the support she asks, we
must be instructed in the elements
of sociology. A member of this
University said to me that although
he knew there was a great deal of
evil going on in our city, he did not
know how to help stop it. He asked
me what he should do when he became a man. Many of us are asking similar questions. We should
like very much to be answered.

The writer is a freshman at Hopkins, and begs for enough space
to complain of the absence of wastepaper baskets in those parts of the
University which he frequents. He
has seen only two of these necessities in McCoy Hall-one in the
office of the registrar and one in
the basement, near the postoffice.
In all of the classrooms he visits
in this building there are no receptacles for waste paper. Is he,
when he has paper to throw away,
to be compelled to walk to the registrar's office or the basement? In
the physics laboratory, where the
writer attends his mathematics
class, he has 'yet to have the pleasure of seeing a proper place to
throw waste paper and old test
papers.
It appears that I am not the
only student needing this commodity. Last week I saw a sophomore,
"bold and cruel," walk hurriedly
out of a classroom on the second
floor of McCoy Hall and go half
way down the stairs to the landing
to place a handful of finely torn-up
paper in the large green tub in
which a rubber plant grows. Then
he went back up stairs. I also
noticed a student in the physics
laboratory raise a window in that
building and throw out in the street

The Intercollegiate Socialist Society,
which was started among the students
in colleges and universities in New York
and other cities of this State more
than three years ago, formed in seven
more colleges in October and November.
These are Princeton, Amherst, Wesleyan, Colgate, Ohio State, Oberlin and the
University of Missouri. The total number of chapters is thirty-seven.
The third annual convention of the
society will be held in this city on December 28 and 29. Among those expected to speak are Mayor-elect Dr.
George R. Lunn of Schenectady, Prof.
V. D. Scudder of Wellesley, Congressman Victor L. Berger, John Spargo, J.

THE NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 11, 191.1.
Outside Impressions.

Co-eds'Cozy Corner
December 7, 1911.
To the Editor of

THE NEWS-LETTER:

That was a clever and interesting
article on "Meeting the Co-eds
and Then —," in the last issue of
THE NEWS-LETTER, but the logic
was all wrong, and no self-respecting "co-ed" would ever permit herself to be "picked up" in this
fashion.
The male undergraduate is a
species which I never could understand. I recall a villainous one to
Whom I was once formally introduced. This was at the college I
attended before coming to Johns
Hopkins. I had maintained speaking relations with this young man
for two weeks and then we met at
a frat affair and somehow he
brought me home.
It was moonlight and it is said
that moonlight is responsible for
many crimes. That I do not know,
but I do know that after he had unlocked the door and was saying
good night," he kissed me. Think
of it! two weeks' acquaintance, and
a kiss—not a mere attempt.
An innocent girl like me! I
Shrank from him in horror, and I
• think that when that villain saw the
look of contempt and anger in my
eyes he was half sorry. I panted
With indignation. I strove to pull
myself together sufficiently to express the scorn which was surging
in my bosom. I thought of the
heating which he would get when
I told my father of the occurrence.
I thought of the subsequent publicity; the long, illustrated accounts
of this awful crime and the punishment which would appear in the
Papers when the correspondents got
Wind of the story.
Hat in hand, and head bowed
down, he turned to go. My blazing eyes and crimson cheeks told
!lim it was dangerous to remain
longer. I was in evening dress with
no hatpins; but hair pins are no
mean weapons in a pinch. He
seemed afraid to speak out and I
struggled to find words before he
left to express my contempt. I
determined to find words or die in
the attempt.
"When," I finally asked, in a low,
faltering voice, full of deep-seated
hatred, "are you coming again ?"
'rhe rest I leave to your imagination.
Co-education may be all right,
but I came to Johns Hopkins to
study and after that episode at
College, I lost two evenings
a week to this villainous young
man, and when we parted his heart
nearly broke.
No more undergraduates for me.
When I need diversion I go to the
moving pictures, and as for being
"Picked up," that would be the last
thing I'd ever consent to. I want
tO study, and my subjects will not
be men. There will be time enough
for that, for I am still young.
Please do not publish my name.
k

CO-ED.

One of the things that strikes a
person here at Hopkins is the really
double life that the students lead.
A student could be the most abandoned, rip-roaring sinner imaginable after class hours, and nobody
would be any the wiser. We gather
here for a few hours each day, see
each other and think we know each
other; do we? How many of us
know with whom any of the rest
of us eat, with whom they spend
their idle hours, or where their
favorite haunts are situated? A
man could eat all his meals at the
Goldfield Hotel, have "Al" Herford for his bosom friend, and spend
all his evenings at Westport, without his university "friends" thinking him anything but a very proper
fellow. Some conveniences in not
being out at Homewood yet, aren't
there?
A man who visits Levering Hall
will find all of the students there
doing one of two things: frantically
writing out exercises or stupidly
dozing. The same condition of affairs seems to exist in the library.
The reason isn't far to seek. By
the time a man has completed all
his class assignments and taken the
amount of physical exercise necesgary to keep him in health, he
doesn't feel fit for much of anything but sleep. No browsing
among the poets in these classic
halls! No time for Woodrow Wilson clubs or such things! We afford a noble example of concentration. Our aims are unified, our
reading is systematized, our otherwise wandering faculties are directed into the straight channel of science and health.
Has the difference between a
course in composition and a course
in Latin, or physics, or political
economy ever been pointed out? In
Latin, or political economy, or physics, a man who reads in a book long
and faithfully enough is bound to
do excellent work. He gets something out of the book and in recitation hands it back to the professor.
In a composition course the work is
purely original. The student finds
his material where Ile can. He must
select what he will use and what
he will reject. That which he
chooses to use he must classify, arrange, proportion and then express.
Some difference, isn't there?

which had not seen him since he
refused the presidency of Princeton. As he came into the room
the students began clapping very
loudly. The action was evidently
quite unexpected by Dr. Pinney.
He turned red as a beet and after
remaining speechless for several
minutes, exclaimed: "Gentlemen,
you are not half as glad as I am."

THE NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 11, 1911.
COLUMBIA'S WAGE EARNERS
Earnings of Students in Various EmPloyments Last Year Were $75,700.
Employment Committee's Work.

Students at Columbia University
during the year ended May, 1911,
earned $75,700. This amount is below the student earnings of the preceding year, but according to the
report of the Employment Committee, recently issued from the University, there were more places filled
by the Committee than in any other
single year. Furthermore, the success of the men employed has given
the Committee a prestige that it has
never before enjoyed and opened up
employment which was closed to
university students.
An explanation of the striking decrease of the total earnings of the
students in the past academic year
as compared with the high-water
mark of the year before, when earnings were $166,778, is given in the
report. "This discrepancy of nearly
$100,000," the report says, "is exPlained by the fact that excepting
the records for the summer vacation of 1910, the Committee endeavored to obtain a report of the
earnings of only those students actuallY registered in the Committee's
list, whereas previously all the students in the University were requested to furnish a record of their
earnings. Instead of asking 4,000
students to report their earnings,
the Committee asked only 820, the
number applying for employment."
Since the first report of the Comniittee for the year 1898-1899 was
Published, the student earnings have
amounted to a total of $904,003.
With the Committee's aid, earnings were $296,445, and without the
Committee's aid, $607,558. The
ratio of earnings with and without
the Committee's aid apparently remains the same from year to year,
although it varies as to the number
of students, who look more to their
own efforts to obtain employment
rather than to those of the Committee to obtain employment for them.
An interesting point is brought
out in the report in regard to freshmen obtaining employment such as
will support them for the first year.
It is only the exceptional man that
can count on paying his way during
this initial year.
•
-About fifty students find employment as stenographers," says the report, "and students coming to the
University with a knowledge of stenography and typewriting will find
it particularly easy to get something
to do. Nearly every one who applied for typewriting work got at
least a small amount. No other class
of work includes more than 2 per
cent, of the number of positions
filled, among the other most popular
demands being camp and hotel
Work, and that in social settlements.
"Teaching paid graduate students
best, for they earned a total of $6,30 without and $3,609 with the

students come second, totaling $1,-

E. B. TAYLOR

Dr. L. L. Uhl, A. B., '89, before
his university course in the Johns
Hopkins University, opened a high
school in Guntur, British India, in
1873, working until it was ripe
for the establishment of a college,
in 1885. He is now principal of
this college.
Where, in 1873, there were not
800 students of all ages and sexes
in Guntur, there are now 3,940 pupils. The college and the General
Synod Lutheran Mission, with
which Dr. Uhl is connected, are
responsible for the majority of these
students and for the largest part of
the many educational changes;
2,179 of the whole number of pupils being in.the college and its high
school, the high school for girls,
and other mission schools, of which
there are, all told, twenty-four mission schools in the town. These
schools are under eight different
American men and women of the
mission.
Guntur is an interior town of
40,000 population and with good
business in argicultural productions.
Long-Distance Nerve.
The city editor of one of the
New York afternoon papers has a
wonderful nose for news, but is
lacking somewhat in a sense of
humor. Once he sent a new reporter up to Harlem to put certain
personal questions to a gentleman
ns ined Flannagan, whose wife had
eloped with a grocery clerk. An
hour passed and then the new reporter called up his city editor on
the telephone, and in a trembling,
shaken voice he said:
"Mr. Blank, I'm nearly killed. I
told Flannagan what you told me
to ask him, and he choked me and
struck me and kicked me all the
way down three flights of steps.
And he says that if I dare to come
back he will kill me."
"Look here," shouted the city
editor; "you go back and find that
man Flannagan and tell him he
can't intimidate me!"— Saturday
Evoling Post.
